<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Four amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic silver(I) and mercury(II) carbene complexes, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Ag(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), and [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Crystal packing revealed a 1D polymeric structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and 2D polymeric structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Four amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic silver(I) and mercury(II) carbene complexes, [(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2Ag2Br2] (3), [Ag(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2]4[Ag4Br8] (4), [Hg(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (5), and [Hg(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (6), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Crystal packing revealed a 1D polymeric structure of 4 and 2D polymeric structure of 3, 5, and 6.

In addition to a repeated interaction between the Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units responsible for the 1D polymeric ladder structure, a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules provided a basis for the other dimension of the polymeric chain. Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is comprised of a unique oligomeric anion [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and four [Ag(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations. Crystal packing of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> revealed a one-dimensional polymeric structure in which the cations are connected to each other through a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions between the adjacent amido groups. Compounds <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are both ionic consisting of a mercury carbene cation and [HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic silver(I) and mercury(II) carbene complexes, [(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2Ag2Br2] (3), [Ag(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2]4[Ag4Br8] (4), [Hg(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (5), and [Hg(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (6), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Crystal packing revealed a 2D polymeric structure of complex 3. In addition to a repeated interaction between the Ag2Br2 units responsible for the 1D polymeric ladder structure, a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules provided a basis for the other dimension of the polymeric chain. Complex 4 is comprised of a unique oligomeric anion [Ag4Br8]4- and four [Ag(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2]+ cations. Crystal packing of 4 revealed a one-dimensional polymeric structure in which the cations are connected to each other through a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions between the adjacent amido groups. Compounds 5 and 6 are both ionic consisting of a mercury carbene cation and [HgBr4]2- anion. An intramolecular interaction of the amido oxygen with the mercury atom of the cation was observed in these two complexes. The interaction between the mercury of the cation and a bromide of the anion, along with the hydrogen bonding interaction of the adjacent amido groups, is responsible for the 2D polymeric structures of these two complexes in the solid state.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Since N-heterocyclic carbene (NHCs) complexes had been independently prepared by Öfele  and Wanzlick and Schönherr  and the first synthesis of a stable N-heterocyclic carbene by Arduengo et al. in 1991 , the chemistry of imidazole-2-ylidene (imy) and benzimidazole-2-ylidene (bimy) have received considerable attention. NHC carbene, a strong σ-donor and a weak π-acceptor, strongly interacts with different transitions metals in various oxidation states . This electronic property combined with the steric effect of the substituents on the nitrogen atoms next to the carbene carbon atom provide a basis for the increased catalytic activity and selectivity of these carbene complexes . Thus, extensive catalytic studies in the field of application to organic synthesis have been reported . Furthermore, the diversity of their structures resulting from, for example, extended metal–metal interactions, metal-bridging halides and carbenes, intermolecular hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions, may lead to interesting structural motifs, such as supramolecular architectures, as well as to inorganic–organic hybrid materials . Our interest has been the influence of a carbene functionalized sidearm on the structural diversity of the related metal carbene complexes. We have reported the acetamide functionalized carbene complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) , in which the amido groups are located on the same side. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules leads to a rectangular architecture. Recently, several structurally diverse acetamide functionalized carbene complexes have been also published by Ghosh and co-workers . Here the results of our recent studies of the silver and mercury complexes with amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene are reported. Due to the intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions and the interaction between the packing units, 1D and 2D supramolecular architectures have been obtained.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since N-heterocyclic carbene (NHCs) complexes had been independently prepared by Öfele  and Wanzlick and Schönherr  and the first synthesis of a stable N-heterocyclic carbene by Arduengo et al. in 1991 , the chemistry of imidazole-2-ylidene (imy) and benzimidazole-2-ylidene (bimy) have received considerable attention. NHC carbene, a strong σ-donor and a weak π-acceptor, strongly interacts with different transitions metals in various oxidation states . This electronic property combined with the steric effect of the substituents on the nitrogen atoms next to the carbene carbon atom provide a basis for the increased catalytic activity and selectivity of these carbene complexes . Thus, extensive catalytic studies in the field of application to organic synthesis have been reported . Furthermore, the diversity of their structures resulting from, for example, extended metal-metal interactions, metal-bridging halides and carbenes, intermolecular hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions, may lead to interesting structural motifs, such as supramolecular architectures, as well as to inorganic-organic hybrid materials . Our interest has been the influence of a carbene functionalized sidearm on the structural diversity of the related metal carbene complexes. We have reported the acetamide functionalized carbene complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=PF6, BF4) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=BF4) , in which the amido groups are located on the same side. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules leads to a rectangular architecture. Recently, several structurally diverse acetamide functionalized carbene complexes have been also published by Ghosh and co-workers . Here the results of our recent studies of the silver and mercury complexes with amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene are reported. Due to the intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions and the interaction between the packing units, 1D and 2D supramolecular architectures have been obtained.

Infrared spectra were recorded on a Jasco FT/IR-460 Plus spectrometer with 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> resolution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All solvents and chemicals were of the analytical reagent grade and used as received from the commercial suppliers. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer CHN-2400 microanalyzer. Proton spectra (δ(TMS)=0.00ppm) were recorded either on a Bruker Avance DPX300 or a Bruker Avance II 400 spectrometer operating at 300.130MHz and 400.132MHz, respectively. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Jasco FT/IR-460 Plus spectrometer with 2cm-1 resolution.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination

Crystallographic data collections were carried out on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at 150(2) or 298(2)K. Unit cell parameters were retrieved and refined using denzo-smn  software on all reflections. Data reduction was performed with the denzo-smn  software. An empirical absorption was based on the symmetry-equivalent reflections and was applied to the data using sortav  program. The structure was solved using the shelxs-97  program and refined using shelxl-97  program by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 values. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding mode. Crystallographic data of 3-6 are summarized in  .

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complexes

1-Methylacetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (1)

1-Methylimidazole (84.2mg, 1.0mmol), 2-bromoacetamide (139.8mg, 1.0mmol) and about 15mL of acetonitrile were placed into a 50mL flask. The flask was heated to reflux under nitrogen causing a formation of a white precipitate. After refluxing for 8h, the solvent was removed, and the solid was washed with 20mL of CH2Cl2. The resulting white solid was dissolved in methanol and kept at 0°C for crystallization. Colorless crystals were obtained (94.3mg, 42% yield). Anal. Calc. for C6H10BrN3O: C, 32.75; H, 4.58; N, 19.09. Found: C, 32.63; H, 4.52; N, 19.01%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 9.08 (s, 1H, NCHN), 7.86 (s, 1H, NH 2), 7.68 (s, 2H, CH CH), 7.51 (s, 1H, NH 2), 4.96 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 3.88ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 167.22 (CO), 138.14 (NCN), 124.21 (CHCH), 123.38 (CH CH), 50.92 (CH2), and 36.30ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3373(vw), 3288(m), 3168(s), 2993(vw), 2928(vw), 2851(vw), 2797(vw), 2732(vw), 1687(vs), 1626(w), 1572(w), 1560(w), 1438(vw), 1396(vw), 1342(m), 1304(m), 1263(vw), 1174(m), 1125(vw), 1091(vw), 1036(w), 1018(vw), 972(vw), 864(vw), 843(vw), 787(vw), 756(vw), 675(w), 651(w), 623(m), 598(w), and 551(vw) cm-1.

<ce:section-title>1-Methylacetamido-3-methylimidazol-2-ylidene silver bromide (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1-Acetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (0.4413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and silver oxide (232.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were placed into a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL flask. <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-methylimidazole and <ce:italic>N-</ce:italic>methylbenzimidazole were alkylated with 2-bromoacetamide to afford 1-methylacetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 1-methylacetamido-3-methylbenzimidazolium bromide (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>), respectively, in good yields. Analogous alkylation procedures have been used by Burgess and co-workers  and Ghosh and co-workers  in the preparation of their amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene ligand precursors. In the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra in deuterated DMSO, the diagnostic acidic 2H-imidazolium protons appear at 9.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 9.79<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The amide protons of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (7.51 and 7.86<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (7.68 and 8.03<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) are not equivalent due to a partial double bond character of the C(O)–NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bond. These chemical shifts are slightly downfield compared with those of 2-bromoacetamide (7.25 and 7.62<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm), thereby suggesting the presence of a Br···H–N type hydrogen bonding in solution between the Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion and the amide protons of the cation. Similar hydrogen bonding interactions have been found, for examples, in compound [1-(R)-3-{<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-(<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>-butylacetamido)imidazol-2-ylidene}]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>AgCl (R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>-Bu, <ce:italic>i</ce:italic>-Pr)  and compound [<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-3-[bis(2-pyridyl-methyl)amino]propanamide]CuCl . The <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> taken at 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C both display their amide signals merged into singlets at 7.37 and 7.56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

 N-methylimidazole and N-methylbenzimidazole were alkylated with 2-bromoacetamide to afford 1-methylacetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (1) and 1-methylacetamido-3-methylbenzimidazolium bromide (2) ( ), respectively, in good yields. Analogous alkylation procedures have been used by Burgess and co-workers  and Ghosh and co-workers  in the preparation of their amido-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene ligand precursors. In the 1H NMR spectra in deuterated DMSO, the diagnostic acidic 2H-imidazolium protons appear at 9.08ppm for 1 and 9.79ppm for 2. The amide protons of 1 (7.51 and 7.86ppm) and 2 (7.68 and 8.03ppm) are not equivalent due to a partial double bond character of the C(O)-NH2 bond. These chemical shifts are slightly downfield compared with those of 2-bromoacetamide (7.25 and 7.62ppm), thereby suggesting the presence of a Br⋅⋅⋅H-N type hydrogen bonding in solution between the Br- anion and the amide protons of the cation. Similar hydrogen bonding interactions have been found, for examples, in compound [1-(R)-3-{N-(t-butylacetamido)imidazol-2-ylidene}]2AgCl (R= t-Bu, i-Pr)  and compound [N-(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-3-[bis(2-pyridyl-methyl)amino]propanamide]CuCl . The 1H NMR spectra of 1 and 2 taken at 60°C both display their amide signals merged into singlets at 7.37 and 7.56ppm, respectively.

The solid state molecular structures of 1 and 2 (,   ) provide evidence for the partial double bond character of the C(O)-NH2 bond and the hydrogen bonding between the bromide anion and the amide protons. elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Upon reaction with Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> produced the silver–carbene complexes [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Ag(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (), respectively. With mercury acetate, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> afforded the mercury–carbene complexes [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) (), respectively. At room temperature these N-heterocyclic carbene metal complexes are neither air nor light-sensitive.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Upon reaction with Ag2O, 1 and 2 produced the silver-carbene complexes [(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2Ag2Br2] (3) and [Ag(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2]4[Ag4Br8] (4) (), respectively. With mercury acetate, 1 and 2 afforded the mercury-carbene complexes [Hg(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (5) and [Hg(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2][HgBr4] (6) (), respectively. At room temperature these N-heterocyclic carbene metal complexes are neither air nor light-sensitive.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Formation of the metal carbene complexes is corroborated by the absence of the 2H-imidazolium proton signals in their <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra. For each metal carbene complex the nonequvalent amide protons appear as a pair of singlets (7.31 and 7.63<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); 7.44 and 7.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>); 7.46 and 7.84<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>); 7.67 and 7.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)). These chemical shifts are also slightly downfield from those of 2-bromoacetamide, which was attributed to the effect of the hydrogen bonding in solution. In the <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C spectra of the above complexes the carbene signals appear as sharp singlets at about 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm downfield from that of the (benz)imidazolium salt. The <ce:sup loc="post">107,109</ce:sup>Ag–<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C coupling in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> or the <ce:sup loc="post">199</ce:sup>Hg–<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C coupling in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is not observed, which could be attributed to the fluxional behavior of the labile metal–carbene bonds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Formation of the metal carbene complexes is corroborated by the absence of the 2H-imidazolium proton signals in their 1H NMR spectra. For each metal carbene complex the nonequvalent amide protons appear as a pair of singlets (7.31 and 7.63ppm (3); 7.44 and 7.76ppm (4); 7.46 and 7.84ppm (5); 7.67 and 7.96ppm (6)). These chemical shifts are also slightly downfield from those of 2-bromoacetamide, which was attributed to the effect of the hydrogen bonding in solution. In the 13C spectra of the above complexes the carbene signals appear as sharp singlets at about 40ppm downfield from that of the (benz)imidazolium salt. The 107,109Ag-13C coupling in 3 and 4 or the 199Hg-13C coupling in 5 and 6 is not observed, which could be attributed to the fluxional behavior of the labile metal-carbene bonds .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">An important feature of the silver carbene complexes is their structural diversity in the solid state, which ranges from a simple monomer to different types of polymeric structures . Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a neutral species composed of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)AgBr repeating units. Two of such units are held together by two bridging bromine atoms to form a dimeric structure (a). The crystal packing revealed the 2D polymeric structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A one-dimensional staircase polymer chain is formed through an extended Ag–Br interaction of the Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rhombic structure (b). Each Ag atom coordinated to a carbene carbon and three <ce:italic>u</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging Br ligands is in a tetrahedral environment. The Ag–C<ce:inf loc="post">carb</ce:inf> bond distance of 2.155(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is longer than the sum of individual covalent radii of Ag and C (2.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) , but slightly shorter than that found in [(allyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)Ag][AgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (2.161(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . The Ag–Br distances of 2.6961(5), 2.8211(4), and 2.9215(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å are comparable to other Ag–Br bonds characteristic for tetrahedral coordination . Within the Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rhombic structure, the Br(1)–Ag–Br(1B) angle (104.325(14)°) is larger than the Ag–Br(1)–Ag(A) (75.675(14)°). The Ag–Ag distance is 3.524<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii for two silver atoms .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: An important feature of the silver carbene complexes is their structural diversity in the solid state, which ranges from a simple monomer to different types of polymeric structures . Complex 3 is a neutral species composed of (CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)AgBr repeating units. Two of such units are held together by two bridging bromine atoms to form a dimeric structure (a). The crystal packing revealed the 2D polymeric structure of 3. A one-dimensional staircase polymer chain is formed through an extended Ag-Br interaction of the Ag2Br2 rhombic structure (b). Each Ag atom coordinated to a carbene carbon and three u 3-bridging Br ligands is in a tetrahedral environment. The Ag-Ccarb bond distance of 2.155(3)Å is longer than the sum of individual covalent radii of Ag and C (2.11Å) , but slightly shorter than that found in [(allyl-imy-CH3)Ag][AgI2] (2.161(9)Å) . The Ag-Br distances of 2.6961(5), 2.8211(4), and 2.9215(5)Å are comparable to other Ag-Br bonds characteristic for tetrahedral coordination . Within the Ag2Br2 rhombic structure, the Br(1)-Ag-Br(1B) angle (104.325(14)°) is larger than the Ag-Br(1)-Ag(A) (75.675(14)°). The Ag-Ag distance is 3.524Å, which is slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii for two silver atoms .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In addition to the extended Ag–Br interaction, an intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the amide NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> protons and the adjacent amide oxygen atom was also found. As shown in c, each amido group of the repeating unit of the one-dimensional polymer is hydrogen bonded to the adjacent amido group of the repeating unit forming a 2D supramolecular architecture. The N···O distance of 2.936<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is smaller than the sum of the van der Waals radii of N and O atoms (3.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . Indeed, the same type of the dimer structure is also found for the amido-functionalized metal carbene complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition to the extended Ag-Br interaction, an intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the amide NH2 protons and the adjacent amide oxygen atom was also found. As shown in c, each amido group of the repeating unit of the one-dimensional polymer is hydrogen bonded to the adjacent amido group of the repeating unit forming a 2D supramolecular architecture. The N⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.936Å is smaller than the sum of the van der Waals radii of N and O atoms (3.05Å) . Indeed, the same type of the dimer structure is also found for the amido-functionalized metal carbene complexes 4-6.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The molecular structure of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is shown in . Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> being ionic, the unit cell consists of two [Ag(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-Bim-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations (a) and one half of the oligomeric [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion (b). The cations C–Ag–C angles are 170.6(3) and 169.6(3)°, which is consistent with other linear [Ag(carbene)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> complexes . The Ag–C distances are 2.096(9), 2.097(8), 2.103(8) and 2.113(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Although these bond distances are shorter than those found in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, they fall in the range of Ag–C bond distances (2.074(5)–2.131(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) generally found in other Ag–NHC complexes . The crystal packing reveals the 1D polymeric structure of the cations through the hydrogen bonding between the amido groups of the adjacent cations. The N···O distances are 2.912 and 2.956<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Hydrogen bonding was also found between the amido group and the DMSO solvent molecule. The closest distances between the amido nitrogen and the oxygen atom of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO are 2.837 and 2.873<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The molecular structure of complex 4 is shown in . Complex 4 being ionic, the unit cell consists of two [Ag(CH3-Bim-CH2CONH2)2]+ cations (a) and one half of the oligomeric [Ag4Br8]4- anion (b). The cations C-Ag-C angles are 170.6(3) and 169.6(3)°, which is consistent with other linear [Ag(carbene)2]+ complexes . The Ag-C distances are 2.096(9), 2.097(8), 2.103(8) and 2.113(8)Å. Although these bond distances are shorter than those found in 3, they fall in the range of Ag-C bond distances (2.074(5)-2.131(5)Å) generally found in other Ag-NHC complexes . The crystal packing reveals the 1D polymeric structure of the cations through the hydrogen bonding between the amido groups of the adjacent cations. The N⋅⋅⋅O distances are 2.912 and 2.956Å. Hydrogen bonding was also found between the amido group and the DMSO solvent molecule. The closest distances between the amido nitrogen and the oxygen atom of (CH3)2SO are 2.837 and 2.873Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The unique oligomeric [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>anion is formed by four Ag atoms and eight bromine atoms. The Ag atoms are either in the distorted trigonal or tetrahedral environments, and three four-membered rings can be observed. Atoms Ag(3), Br(1), Ag(3A), and Br(1A) form an almost perfect square with 90.97(3)° and 89.03(3)° angles. The Ag–Br distance for a terminal bromide is 2.5395(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Ag–Br distances for the bridging bromides are longer falling in the range of 2.6454(13)–2.7941(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Ag···Ag distances are 3.504 and 3.828<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å suggesting no Ag–Ag interaction within the anion. To our knowledge, [K(crypt-2,2,2)]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] is the only example of a compound containing oligomeric [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion that has been reported in literature . However, the bond distances and angles of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> in [K(crypt-2,2,2)]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] are different from those found in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. In [K(crypt-2,2,2)]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>], the terminal Ag–Br distances are shorter (2.518(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and the bridging Ag–Br distances are falling in a wider range (2.631(2)–2.799(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and the Ag···Ag distances are 3.562(1) and 3.595(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The angles of the “square” formed by the Ag(3), Br(1), Ag(3A) and Br(1A) atoms in [K(crypt-2,2,2)]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] are 96.87(4)° and 83.13(4)° . Different cations in these two compounds resulting in different crystal packing forces could account for such a difference in the bond distances and angles of the anions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The unique oligomeric [Ag4Br8]4-anion is formed by four Ag atoms and eight bromine atoms. The Ag atoms are either in the distorted trigonal or tetrahedral environments, and three four-membered rings can be observed. Atoms Ag(3), Br(1), Ag(3A), and Br(1A) form an almost perfect square with 90.97(3)° and 89.03(3)° angles. The Ag-Br distance for a terminal bromide is 2.5395(12)Å. The Ag-Br distances for the bridging bromides are longer falling in the range of 2.6454(13)-2.7941(12)Å. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances are 3.504 and 3.828Å suggesting no Ag-Ag interaction within the anion. To our knowledge, [K(crypt-2,2,2)]4[Ag4Br8] is the only example of a compound containing oligomeric [Ag4Br8]4- anion that has been reported in literature . However, the bond distances and angles of [Ag4Br8]4- in [K(crypt-2,2,2)]4[Ag4Br8] are different from those found in 4. In [K(crypt-2,2,2)]4[Ag4Br8], the terminal Ag-Br distances are shorter (2.518(2)Å) and the bridging Ag-Br distances are falling in a wider range (2.631(2)-2.799(2)Å), and the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances are 3.562(1) and 3.595(2)Å. The angles of the "square" formed by the Ag(3), Br(1), Ag(3A) and Br(1A) atoms in [K(crypt-2,2,2)]4[Ag4Br8] are 96.87(4)° and 83.13(4)° . Different cations in these two compounds resulting in different crystal packing forces could account for such a difference in the bond distances and angles of the anions.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, an ionic compound, two [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and two [HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions with slightly different bond distances and angles are found in the unit cell. The C–Hg–C angle values found for each cation (179.999(2)° and 179.999(3)°) are consistent with those found for 1,3-diphenylimidzol-2-ylidene mercury perchlorate (180°) . The Hg–C bond distances are 2.078(9) and 2.051(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The previously reported mercury carbene Hg–C bond distances fall into the range of 1.97(2)–2.22(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . Unlike the silver complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the mercury complex is characterized by an interaction between an amide oxygen and the mercury atom. The Hg···O distances of 2.794 and 2.802<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of O and Hg atoms (3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) , suggesting a weak interaction of the amide group with the Hg atom, which may be resulted from the higher oxidation state of the mercury ion compared with that of the Ag(I) in the silver carbene complexes. The Hg–Br distances of the anions are falling in the range of 2.5796(11)–2.6351(11)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Crystal packing revealed a 2D polymeric structure of complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. One dimension of the polymer chain is forged by the Hg···Br interaction between the anion and the cation. The Hg(1)···Br(2) and Hg(2)···Br(1) distances are 3.227 and 3.386<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. These distances are within the sum of the van der Waals radii of Br and Hg atoms (3.3–3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . The hydrogen bonds between the amido groups of the adjacent cations constitute the other dimension of the polymer chain. The N···O distance for the adjacent amido groups is 2.901<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For complex 5, an ionic compound, two [Hg(CH3-imy-CH2CONH2)2]2+ cations and two [HgBr4]2- anions with slightly different bond distances and angles are found in the unit cell. The C-Hg-C angle values found for each cation (179.999(2)° and 179.999(3)°) are consistent with those found for 1,3-diphenylimidzol-2-ylidene mercury perchlorate (180°) . The Hg-C bond distances are 2.078(9) and 2.051(9)Å. The previously reported mercury carbene Hg-C bond distances fall into the range of 1.97(2)-2.22(3)Å . Unlike the silver complexes 3 and 4, the mercury complex is characterized by an interaction between an amide oxygen and the mercury atom. The Hg⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.794 and 2.802Å are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of O and Hg atoms (3.0Å) , suggesting a weak interaction of the amide group with the Hg atom, which may be resulted from the higher oxidation state of the mercury ion compared with that of the Ag(I) in the silver carbene complexes. The Hg-Br distances of the anions are falling in the range of 2.5796(11)-2.6351(11)Å. Crystal packing revealed a 2D polymeric structure of complex 5. One dimension of the polymer chain is forged by the Hg⋅⋅⋅Br interaction between the anion and the cation. The Hg(1)⋅⋅⋅Br(2) and Hg(2)⋅⋅⋅Br(1) distances are 3.227 and 3.386Å, respectively. These distances are within the sum of the van der Waals radii of Br and Hg atoms (3.3-3.5Å) . The hydrogen bonds between the amido groups of the adjacent cations constitute the other dimension of the polymer chain. The N⋅⋅⋅O distance for the adjacent amido groups is 2.901Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Previously we have prepared the mercury amido-functionalized carbene complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) . The interaction between mercury and nitrogen atoms of the pyrazinyl (pyrimidyl) substitute produced a skewed Hg–carbene core conformation that forced the two amido groups to be on the same side and formed a U-shaped building block. In the crystal packing, the intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the adjacent amido groups connects the U-shaped building blocks leading to a rectangular architecture. In the alkyl- substituted analog of complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> lacking the Hg–N interaction found in complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>), a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-anti conformation precluded the U-shaped conformations of the amido groups and the resulting rectangular architecture. It is noteworthy that without the Hg–N interaction, a weak interaction between the amido oxygen and the mercury atom was observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Previously we have prepared the mercury amido-functionalized carbene complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=PF6, BF4) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=BF4) . The interaction between mercury and nitrogen atoms of the pyrazinyl (pyrimidyl) substitute produced a skewed Hg-carbene core conformation that forced the two amido groups to be on the same side and formed a U-shaped building block. In the crystal packing, the intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between the adjacent amido groups connects the U-shaped building blocks leading to a rectangular architecture. In the alkyl- substituted analog of complex 5 lacking the Hg-N interaction found in complexes [Hg(2-pyrazinyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=PF6, BF4) and [Hg(2-pyrimidyl-imy-CH2CONH2)2]X (X=BF4), a trans-anti conformation precluded the U-shaped conformations of the amido groups and the resulting rectangular architecture. It is noteworthy that without the Hg-N interaction, a weak interaction between the amido oxygen and the mercury atom was observed.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is also an ionic compound, containing two [Hg(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bimy-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CONH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and two [HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions in the unit cell. The C–Hg–C angles of the two cations are 174.8(6)° and 176.5(6)°. The Hg–C bond distances are 2.070(15), 2.089(15), 2.064(16) and 2.121(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Hg–Br bond distances of the anions are falling in the range of 2.5501(19)–2.6753(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The weak interactions and the 2D polymeric structure observed for complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are also found in complex <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. The Hg···O distances between mercury and oxygen atoms of the amido group are 2.802 and 2.827<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Hg(1) and 2.780 and 3.040<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Hg(2). The Hg···Br distances between the cation and the anion are in the range of 3.193–3.483<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N···O distances for the adjacent amido group of the cations are determined to be 2.880, 2.960, 2.847 and 2.922<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Hydrogen bonds between the amido group and the solvent molecule are also found in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. The closest (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO···N distances between the amido nitrogen and oxygen of DMSO are 2.894 and 3.352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. It is noteworthy that many carbene complexes containing benzimidazole-2-ylidene display a π–π stacking interactions between the aromatic rings of the adjacent molecules . This type of interaction was not found in complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, possibly due to the stronger hydrogen bonding interaction between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 6 is also an ionic compound, containing two [Hg(CH3-bimy-CH2CONH2)2]2+ cations and two [HgBr4]2- anions in the unit cell. The C-Hg-C angles of the two cations are 174.8(6)° and 176.5(6)°. The Hg-C bond distances are 2.070(15), 2.089(15), 2.064(16) and 2.121(15)Å. The Hg-Br bond distances of the anions are falling in the range of 2.5501(19)-2.6753(18)Å. The weak interactions and the 2D polymeric structure observed for complex 5 are also found in complex 6. The Hg⋅⋅⋅O distances between mercury and oxygen atoms of the amido group are 2.802 and 2.827Å for Hg(1) and 2.780 and 3.040Å for Hg(2). The Hg⋅⋅⋅Br distances between the cation and the anion are in the range of 3.193-3.483Å. The N⋅⋅⋅O distances for the adjacent amido group of the cations are determined to be 2.880, 2.960, 2.847 and 2.922Å. Hydrogen bonds between the amido group and the solvent molecule are also found in 6. The closest (CH3)2SO⋅⋅⋅N distances between the amido nitrogen and oxygen of DMSO are 2.894 and 3.352Å. It is noteworthy that many carbene complexes containing benzimidazole-2-ylidene display a π-π stacking interactions between the aromatic rings of the adjacent molecules . This type of interaction was not found in complexes 4 and 6, possibly due to the stronger hydrogen bonding interaction between the amido groups of the adjacent molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, the amido-functionalized carbene ligand precursors and corresponding silver and mercury carbene complexes have been prepared and characterized. While <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a neutral compound, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are ionic. In addition to the metal–carbene interaction, a weak interaction between the amide oxygen and the mercury atom were also found in complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, possibly due to the higher oxidation state of mercury. A hydrogen bonding interaction of the amido groups of the adjacent cations is responsible for the one-dimensional polymeric structure found in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. In addition to the hydrogen bonding, an extended Ag–Br interaction in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the interaction between the cation and the anion in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> constitute another dimension of the polymeric structure resulting in a two-dimensional supramolecular architecture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, the amido-functionalized carbene ligand precursors and corresponding silver and mercury carbene complexes have been prepared and characterized. While 3 is a neutral compound, 4-6 are ionic. In addition to the metal-carbene interaction, a weak interaction between the amide oxygen and the mercury atom were also found in complexes 5 and 6, possibly due to the higher oxidation state of mercury. A hydrogen bonding interaction of the amido groups of the adjacent cations is responsible for the one-dimensional polymeric structure found in 4. In addition to the hydrogen bonding, an extended Ag-Br interaction in 3 and the interaction between the cation and the anion in 5 and 6 constitute another dimension of the polymeric structure resulting in a two-dimensional supramolecular architecture.

Preparation of complexes

1-Methylacetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (1)

1-Methylimidazole (84.2mg, 1.0mmol), 2-bromoacetamide (139.8mg, 1.0mmol) and about 15mL of acetonitrile were placed into a 50mL flask. The flask was heated to reflux under nitrogen causing a formation of a white precipitate. After refluxing for 8h, the solvent was removed, and the solid was washed with 20mL of CH2Cl2. The resulting white solid was dissolved in methanol and kept at 0°C for crystallization. Colorless crystals were obtained (94.3mg, 42% yield). Anal. Calc. for C6H10BrN3O: C, 32.75; H, 4.58; N, 19.09. Found: C, 32.63; H, 4.52; N, 19.01%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 9.08 (s, 1H, NCHN), 7.86 (s, 1H, NH 2), 7.68 (s, 2H, CH CH), 7.51 (s, 1H, NH 2), 4.96 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 3.88ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 167.22 (CO), 138.14 (NCN), 124.21 (CHCH), 123.38 (CH CH), 50.92 (CH2), and 36.30ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3373(vw), 3288(m), 3168(s), 2993(vw), 2928(vw), 2851(vw), 2797(vw), 2732(vw), 1687(vs), 1626(w), 1572(w), 1560(w), 1438(vw), 1396(vw), 1342(m), 1304(m), 1263(vw), 1174(m), 1125(vw), 1091(vw), 1036(w), 1018(vw), 972(vw), 864(vw), 843(vw), 787(vw), 756(vw), 675(w), 651(w), 623(m), 598(w), and 551(vw) cm-1.

1-Methylacetamido-3-methylbenzimidazolium bromide (2)

The preparation of [CH3-Bim-CH2CONH2]Br was similar to that of compound 1. From 132.1mg of 1-methylbenzimidazole (1.0mmol) and 139.6mg of 2-bromoacetamide (1.0mmol), 189.0mg of colorless crystals were obtained (70.0% yield). Anal. Calc. for C10H12BrN3O: C, 44.46; H, 4.48; N, 15.56. Found: C, 44.44; H, 4.49; N, 15.51%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 9.79 (s, 1H, NCHN), 8.03 (m, 2H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 7.94 (m, 1H, C6 H 4), 7.68 (m, 3H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 5.33 (s, 2H, CH2 ), and 4.13ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 167.00 (CO), 144.15 (NCN), 131.97, 131.92, 127.16, 126.92, 114.11, 113.92 (C 6H4), 48.79 (CH2), and 33.88ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3305(vw), 3236(vw), 3138(s), 3033(vw), 2979(vw), 2942(vw), 1793(vw), 1691(vs), 1680(vs), 1612(w), 1568(m), 1487(vw), 1460(w), 1444(w), 1414(vw), 1387(m), 1367(vw), 1346(vw), 1292(m), 1279(w), 1215(w), 1203(w), 1165(vw), 1142(vw), 1128(vw), 1111(vw), 1090(vw), 1030(vw), 1012(vw), 980(vw), 941(vw), 902(vw), 845(vw), 804(vw), 767(m), 756(m), 652(vw), 617(vw), 595(vw), 569(w), 534(vw), 507(vw), and 426(w) cm-1.

1-Methylacetamido-3-methylimidazol-2-ylidene silver bromide (3)

1-Acetamido-3-methylimidazolium bromide (0.4413g, 2.0mmol) and silver oxide (232.1mg, 1.0mmol) were placed into a 50mL flask. The flask was covered with aluminium foil followed by a transfer of about 20mL of CH2Cl2 into the flask. After stirring for 1day, the solution was removed by filtration and the resulting white solid was washed with CH2Cl2 several times. The resulting white solid was dissolved in DMSO for crystallization. Colorless crystals were obtained (241.9mg, 37% yield). Anal. Calc. for C12H18Ag2Br2N6O2: C, 22.04; H, 2.77; N, 12.85. Found: C, 22.07; H, 2.90; N, 12.78%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 7.63 (s, 1H, NH 2), 7.37 (s, 2H, CH CH), 7.31 (s, 1H, NH 2), 4.75 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 3.77ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 181.65 (NCN), 169.06 (CO), 123.87 (CHCH), 122.87 (CH CH), 53.21 (CH2), and 38.54ppm (CH3). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3398(m), 3306(vw), 3237(vw), 3184(w), 3138(vw), 3107(vw), 2935(vw), 1683(s), 1621(w), 1568(vw), 1549(vw), 1471(vw), 1449(vw), 1430(vw), 1401(vw), 1391(w), 1357(vw), 1341(vw), 1308(w), 1230(w), 1193(vw), 1139(vw), 1100(vw), 1081(vw), 1032(vw), 962(vw), 875(vw), 824(vw), 801(vw), 760(vw), 717(w), 702(vw), 622(vw), 610(vw), 553(vw), and 496(w).

[{1-(Methylacetamido)-3-(methylbenzimidazol-2-ylidene)}2Ag]4[Ag4Br8] (4)

The preparation was similar to that of 3. From 541.2mg (2.0mmol) of 1-acetamido-3-methylbenzimidazolium bromide and 230.5mg (1.0mmol) of silver oxide, 750.4mg (98%) of 4 ⋅2H2O was isolated after washing with CH2Cl2. A crystal suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis was isolated from DMSO solution. Anal. Calc. for C80H88Ag8Br8N24O8 ⋅2H2O: C, 31.48; H, 3.04; N, 11.01. Found: C, 31.33; H, 3.07; N, 11.07%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 7.76 (m, 2H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 7.64 (m, 1H, C6 H 4), 7.44 (m, 3H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 5.12 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 4.05ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 192.31 (NCN), 168.69 (CO), 134.42, 134.25, 124.44, 124.29, 112.38 (C 6H4), 50.99 (CH2), and 36.00ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3332(m), 3318(m), 3161(m), 3034(vw), 2993(vw), 2977(vw), 2935(w), 2918(w), 2912(w), 2831(vw), 2786(vw), 2360(vw), 2338(vw), 1686(vs), 1641(vw), 1610(vw), 1480(vw), 1465(vw), 1438(s), 1392(s), 1346(vw), 1311(s), 1269(vw), 1204(w), 1173(vw), 1131(vw), 1104(vw), 1033(vw), 1026(s), 978(vw), 951(vw), 932(vw), 867(vw), 821(vw), 792(vw), 764(s), 740(s), 710(vw), 618(m), 606(m), 580(m), 508(vw), and 434(w) cm-1.

[{1-(Methylacetamido)-3-(methylimidazol-2-ylidene)}2Hg][HgBr4] (5)

1-Acetamido-3-methylimidzolium bromide (110.7mg, 0.5mmol) and mercury acetate (81.0mg, 0.25mmol) were placed into a 50mL flask followed by a transfer of about 20mL of CH3CN into the flask. After refluxing for 1day, the solution was removed by filtration, and the resulting white solid was washed with CH3CN several times. A white solid was obtained (99.3mg, 39.8% yield). Anal. Calc. for C12H18Br4Hg2N6O2: C, 14.43; H, 1.82; N, 8.41. Found: C, 14.33.82; H, 1.90; N, 8.49%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 7.84 (s, 1H, NH 2), 7.64 (s, 1H, CH CH), 7.63 (s, 1H, CHCH), 7.46 (s, 1H, NH 2), 5.17 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 3.98ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 177.66 (NCN), 168.74 (CO), 124.96 (CHCH), 124.36 (CH CH), 52.46 (CH2), and 38.22ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3353(m), 3279(s), 3149(s), 3122(s), 2965(vw), 2924(vw), 2801(vw), 2755(vw), 2357(vw), 2287(vw), 2219(vw), 1943(vw), 1683(vs), 1621(w), 1568(vw), 1479(w), 1442(w), 1421(vw), 1410(vw), 1391(m), 1257(w), 1203(w), 1162(vw), 1139(vw), 1085(vw), 1062(vw), 1020(vw), 970(vw), 890(vw), 863(vw), 813(w), 797(vw), 764(s), 687(m), 656(m), 626(w), and 453(vw) cm-1.

[{1-(Methylacetamido)-3-(methylimidazol-2-ylidene)}2Hg][HgBr4] (6)

The preparation was similar to that of 5, except that 135.3mg (0.5mmol) of 1-acetamido-3-methylbenzimidazolium bromide, 81.0mg (0.25mmol) of mercury acetate and 43.0mg (0.25mmol) of sodium acetate were used. A white solid was obtained (120.8mg, 44% yield). Anal. Calc. for C20H22Br4Hg2N6O2: C, 21.86; H, 2.02; N, 7.65. Found: C, 21.67; H, 2.09; N, 7.71%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 7.96 (m, 2H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 7.82 (m, 1H, C6 H 4), 7.67 (m, 3H, C6 H 4, NH 2), 5.54 (s, 2H, CH 2), and 4.28ppm (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 184.64 (NCN), 168.24 (CO), 133.70, 126.25, 126.07, 113.42, 112.97 (C 6H4), 50.08 (CH2) and 35.83ppm (CH3). IR (KBr): 3348(w), 3328(w), 3304(w), 3249(vw), 3165(m), 3046(vw), 2916(vw), 2360(vw), 2337(vw), 1675(vs), 1609(w), 1568(vw), 1487(vw), 1461(s), 1418(w), 1403(m), 1362(w), 1351(vw), 1327(w), 1277(vw), 1261(vw), 1215(w), 1181(vw), 1139(vw), 1112(vw), 1028(vw), 974(vw), 939(vw), 886(vw), 836(vw), 794(w), 756(vw), 663(s), 652(w), 626(w), 614(w), and 576(w) cm-1.
